intro: Didiscus coeruleus var. typicus, commonly known as the blue-eyed Mary, is a flowering plant native to southern Europe and parts of North Africa. It is a member of the Boraginaceae family and is characterized by its striking blue or violet flowers with a white or yellow center. The plant typically grows to a height of 10–30 cm and produces small, oval-shaped leaves that are often hairy. It thrives in well-drained soil and full sun, making it a popular choice for rock gardens and borders. The flowers bloom in late spring to early summer, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies.
